results.question: When will the Automatic SOS be triggered?
results.ground_truth_answer: The Automatic SOS will be triggered in the event that your vehicle's airbags deploy.
results.generated_response: The Automatic SOS is activated automatically **when the vehicle’s airbags deploy**. At that moment the system initiates a hands‑free emergency call to connect you with help.
retrieved_chunks:
Automatic SOS — If Equipped Automatic SOS is a hands-free safety service that can immediately connect you with help in the event that your vehicle’s airbags deploy.  Please refer to your provided radio supplement for complete information.

 SOS Call Push the SOS Call button on the overhead console.  Note: in case the sos call button is pushed in error, there will be a 10 second delay before the sos call system initiates a call to an sos operator.  To cancel the SOS Call connection, push the SOS call button on the overhead console or press the cancellation button on the Device Screen.  Termination of the SOS Call will turn off the green LED light on the overhead console.  The LED light located within the ASSIST and SOS buttons on the overhead console will turn green once a connection to an SOS operator has been made.  Once a connection between the vehicle and an sos operator is made, the sos call system may transmit the following important vehicle information to an sos operator: indication that the occupant placed an sos call.  The vehicle brand.  The last known GPS coordinates of the vehicle.  You should be able to speak with the SOS operator through the vehicle audio system to determine if additional help is needed.  Warning: always obey traffic laws and pay attention to the road.  ALWAYS drive safely with your hands on the steering wheel.  You have full responsibility and assume all risks related to the use of the features and applications in this vehicle.  Only use the features and applications when it is safe to do so.  Failure to do so may result in an accident involving serious injury or death.  Note: your vehicle may be transmitting data as authorized by the subscriber.  Once a connection is made between the vehicle’s SOS Call system and the SOS operator, the SOS operator may be able to open a voice connection with the vehicle to determine if additional help is needed.  Once the SOS operator opens a voice connection with the vehicle’s SOS Call system, the operator should be able to speak with the vehicle occupants, and hear sounds occurring in the vehicle.  The vehicle’s SOS Call system will attempt to remain connected with the SOS operator until the SOS operator terminates the connection.  The SOS operator may attempt to contact appropriate emergency responders and provide them with important vehicle information and GPS coordinates.  WARNING: If anyone in the vehicle could be in danger (e.g., fire or smoke is visible, dangerous road conditions or location), do not wait for voice contact from an Emergency Services Agent.  All occupants should exit the vehicle immediately and move to a safe location.  Never place anything on or near the vehicle’s operable network and GPS antennas.  You could prevent operable network and GPS signal reception, which can prevent your vehicle from placing an emergency call.  An operable network and GPS signal reception is required for the SOS Call system to function properly.  The SOS Call system is embedded into the vehicle’s electrical system.  Do not add aftermarket electrical equipment to the vehicle’s electrical system.  This may prevent your vehicle from sending a signal to initiate an emergency call.  To avoid interference that can cause the SOS Call system to fail, never add aftermarket equipment (e.g., two-way mobile radio, CB radio, data recorder, etc.)  to your vehicle’s electrical system or modify the antennas on your vehicle.  IF YOUR VEHICLE LOSES BATTERY POWER FOR ANY REASON (INCLUDING DURING OR AFTER AN ACCIDENT), THE UCONNECT FEATURES, APPS AND SERVICES, AMONG OTHERS, WILL NOT OPERATE.  Modifications to any part of the SOS Call system could cause the air bag system to fail when you need it.  You could be injured if the air bag system is not there to help protect you.

 Connected Services SOS FAQs — If Equipped What happens if I accidentally push the SOS Call button on the mirror or overhead console?  You have 10 seconds after pushing the SOS Call button to cancel the call.  To cancel the call, either push the SOS Call button again, or press the Cancel button on the in-vehicle touchscreen.  What type of information is sent when I use the SOS Call button from my vehicle?  Certain vehicle information, such as make and model, is transmitted along with the last known GPS location.  When could I use the SOS Call button?  You can use the SOS Call button to make a call if you or someone else needs emergency assistance.

results.question: What should I do to jump start the car?
results.ground_truth_answer:
To jump start the car, you should follow these steps:

- Prepare for jump starting by applying the parking brake, shifting the transmission into PARK or NEUTRAL, turning off the ignition, and all electrical accessories.
- Make sure the vehicle providing the jump start is parked within reach of the jumper cables, with the ignition turned OFF.
- Only use the positive battery post on the main battery to jump start your vehicle.
- Avoid using a booster battery greater than 12 Volts.
- Ensure that cable clamps do not touch each other.
- Lift up the protective cap on the positive battery post to gain access.
- Do not allow vehicles to touch each other.
- Avoid the radiator cooling fan when the hood is raised.
- Remove any metal jewelry that could make inadvertent electrical contact.
- Keep open flames or sparks away from the battery.

After following these preparations, you can proceed with the jump starting procedure.
results.generated_response:
**How to Jump‑Start Your Car – Step‑by‑Step (with all safety precautions)**  

---

### 1. Prepare the Vehicles  

1. **Park the cars**  
   * Position the donor (working) vehicle close enough that the jumper‑cable clamps can reach both batteries, but **do not let the two vehicles touch** each other.  
2. **Engage the brakes**  
   * Apply the parking brake on **both** vehicles.  
3. **Set the transmissions**  
   * Automatic: shift to **PARK (P)**.  
   * Manual: shift to **NEUTRAL**.  
4. **Turn off everything**  
   * Set the ignition **OFF** on both vehicles.  
   * Switch off the heater, radio, lights and any other electrical accessories.  

---

### 2. Safety Checks Before Connecting  

| What to watch for | Why it matters |
|-------------------|----------------|
| **Only the main battery’s positive post** | The supplemental battery (if your car has a Stop/Start system) must **not** be used – it can cause serious injury or death. |
| **No frozen battery** | A frozen battery can rupture or explode when a charge is applied. |
| **Voltage limit** | Use only a **12‑volt** source. Boosters or chargers >12 V can damage the battery, starter, alternator, or vehicle electronics. |
| **Clamp separation** | Keep the **unused ends** of the jumper cables from touching each other, the vehicle frames, or any metal parts. |
| **Flammable gases** | Battery gas (hydrogen) is explosive – keep flames, sparks, and smoking materials away. |
| **Lead exposure** | Battery terminals contain lead; wash hands after handling. |
| **Radiator fan** | When the hood is open, the fan can start automatically. Stay clear of the blades. |
| **Metal jewelry** | Remove rings, bracelets, watches, etc., to avoid accidental short‑circuits. |
| **Acid protection** | Battery acid can burn skin/eyes – avoid contact and have eye‑wash or water nearby. |

---

### 3. Connect the Jumper Cables  

1. **Identify the posts** on your (discharged) battery:  
   * **Positive (+)** – usually covered with a protective cap; lift the cap to expose it.  
   * **Negative (–)** – the plain metal post.  

2. **Attach the clamps in this order** (donor vehicle → dead vehicle):  

   1. **Red clamp** to the **positive (+) post** of the **donor** battery.  
   2. **Red clamp** to the **positive (+) post** of the **dead** battery.  
   3. **Black clamp** to the **negative (–) post** of the **donor** battery.  
   4. **Black clamp** to a **ground point** on the dead‑vehicle chassis (unpainted metal, away from the battery). *Do NOT connect it to the dead battery’s negative post.*  

3. **Double‑check** that no clamps are touching each other or any other metal parts.

---

### 4. Start the Donor Vehicle  

* Start the engine of the donor car and let it run **idle** for a minute or two. This begins charging the dead battery.

---

### 5. Attempt to Start the Discharged Vehicle  

1. Turn the ignition **ON** (if it isn’t already) and try to start the engine.  
2. If it doesn’t start after a few seconds, wait another minute while the donor continues to run, then try again.  

*If the vehicle still won’t start after a few attempts, the battery may be too discharged or damaged, or there may be another issue.*

---

### 6. Disconnect the Cables (reverse order)  

1. **Black clamp** from the chassis ground on the dead vehicle.  
2. **Black clamp** from the donor’s negative post.  
3. **Red clamp** from the dead vehicle’s positive post.  
4. **Red clamp** from the donor’s positive post.  

*Keep the clamps away from each other while removing them.*

---

### 7. After‑Start Actions  

* Keep the revived vehicle’s engine running **at least 15–20 minutes** (or drive it) to allow the alternator to recharge the battery.  
* If you used a portable booster pack, follow the manufacturer’s instructions for disconnecting it.  

---

### 8. Important “Do Not” Reminders  

- **Do not** attempt jump‑starting a **frozen** battery.  
- **Do not** use a **booster** or charger with voltage **>12 V**.  
- **Do not** let the two vehicles **touch** each other.  
- **Do not** let the **unused cable ends** touch each other or any metal surface.  
- **Do not** connect the **negative clamp** to the dead battery’s negative post (use a chassis ground instead).  

---

### Quick Checklist  

| ✅ | Action |
|----|--------|
| ☐ Parking brake applied on both cars |
| ☐ Transmissions in P (auto) or N (manual) |
| ☐ Ignition OFF, accessories OFF |
| ☐ Positive clamps on both + posts |
| ☐ Negative clamp on donor – post, other on chassis ground |
| ☐ Donor engine running |
| ☐ Attempt start of dead vehicle |
| ☐ Remove clamps in reverse order |
| ☐ Keep revived engine running to recharge battery |

---

**Following these steps exactly will let you safely jump‑start your car while minimizing the risk of personal injury, battery explosion, or damage to either vehicle’s electrical system.**

results.question: What should I pay attention to for the clutch pedal?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the provided context, here are the key things to pay attention to regarding the clutch pedal:

1. Fully press the clutch pedal before shifting gears. Pressing the clutch pedal all the way down is necessary when changing gears to prevent damage to the transmission.

2. As you release the clutch pedal, lightly press the accelerator pedal. This coordination of the clutch and accelerator is important for smooth gear shifts.

3. Certain noise from the transmission may be noticeable when the clutch is engaged (pedal released). This noise is normal and not an indication of a problem with the clutch or transmission.

4. Ensure the carpet is securely attached and does not interfere with the operation of the clutch pedal. Unattached or improperly placed carpet could get stuck under the clutch pedal and cause a loss of vehicle control.

In summary, focus on fully pressing and properly releasing the clutch pedal during gear shifts, be aware of normal transmission noises, and ensure the floor carpet does not impact clutch pedal operation.
results.generated_response:
When using the clutch pedal, keep the following points in mind:

1. **Shifting**  
   * Press the clutch **fully down** before you move the gear lever.  
   * As you **release** the clutch, give the accelerator a light tap to match engine speed.

2. **Transmission‑noise awareness**  
   * Some whining or humming from the transmission is normal, especially when the vehicle is idling in neutral with the clutch **released** (pedal up). It does **not** indicate a clutch problem.

3. **Carpet & floor‑mat safety**  
   * Make sure the vehicle carpet is the correct type, securely fastened with its grommets, and does **not** interfere with the clutch pedal travel.  
   * Before driving, **fully depress** the clutch (and the other pedals) to verify there is no obstruction from the carpet, floor mats, or any objects that might have slipped under them.  
   * Never place towels, keys, or other items under the carpet, as they can shift the carpet and block the clutch pedal, leading to loss of control.

4. **General precaution**  
   * Keep the area around the pedal clear and ensure the pedal moves freely through its full range of motion.

By following these steps you’ll protect the clutch mechanism, avoid unintended pedal interference, and maintain safe vehicle operation.

Shifting Fully press the clutch pedal before shifting gears.  As you release the clutch pedal, lightly press the accelerator pedal.  You should always use FIRST gear when starting from a standing position.  Note: A certain amount of noise from the transmission is normal.  This noise can be most noticeable when the vehicle is idling in NEUTRAL with the clutch engaged (clutch pedal released), but it may also be heard when driving.  The noise may also be more noticeable when the transmission is warm.  This noise is normal and is not an indication of a problem with your clutch or transmission.

 Before Climbing A Steep Hill As you approach a hill, consider its grade or steepness.  Determine if it is too steep.  Look to see what the traction is on the hill side trail.  Is the trail straight up and down?  What is on top and the other side?  Are there ruts, rocks, branches or other obstacles on the path?  Can you safely recover the vehicle if something goes wrong?  If everything looks good and you feel confident, shift the transmission into a lower gear with 4L engaged, and proceed with caution, maintaining your momentum as you climb the hill.

 Carpet Safety Information Always use carpet designed to fit your vehicle.  Only use carpet that does not interfere with the operation of the pedal assemblies.  Only operate the vehicle when the carpet is securely attached by the grommets so it cannot slip out of position and interfere with the pedal assemblies or impair safe operation of your vehicle in other ways.  WARNING: If operating the vehicle without carpet in place the floor may become hot, and there is a risk of burns.  An improperly attached, damaged, folded, or damaged grommets may cause your carpet to interfere with the accelerator, brake, or clutch pedals and cause a loss of vehicle control.  To prevent SERIOUS INJURY or DEATH: ALWAYS securely attach your carpet using the grommets.  ALWAYS make sure objects cannot fall or slide into the driver’s side floor area when the vehicle is moving.  Objects can become trapped under accelerator, brake, or clutch pedals and could cause a loss of vehicle control.  NEVER place any objects under the carpet (e.g., towels, keys, etc.).  These objects could change the position of the carpet and may cause interference with the accelerator, brake, or clutch pedals.  ONLY install carpet designed to fit your vehicle.  NEVER install carpet that cannot be properly attached and secured to your vehicle.  If the carpet needs to be replaced, only use manufacturer approved carpet for the specific make, model, and year of your vehicle.  If the vehicle carpet has been removed and re-installed, always properly attach carpet to the floor and check that the floor mat fasteners are secure to the vehicle carpet.  Fully depress each pedal to check for interference with the accelerator, brake, or clutch pedals then re-install the floor mats.

results.question: how to set up Android Auto?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the context provided, here are the steps to set up Android Auto:

1. Download the Android Auto app from the Google Play store on your Android-powered smartphone.

2. Connect your Android-powered smartphone to one of the media USB ports in your vehicle. If the Android Auto app was not previously downloaded, it will begin downloading when you first plug in your device.

3. Make sure your vehicle is in PARK the first time you use the app.

4. Use the factory-provided USB cable that came with your phone, as aftermarket cables may not work.

5. Ensure you are in an area with cellular coverage, as Android Auto may use cellular data from your smartphone's data plan.

6. Once the device is connected and recognized, the Phone icon on the drag & drop menu bar will change to the Android Auto icon.

7. The Android Auto app will display all the compatible apps that can be used with Android Auto. You must have the compatible app downloaded and be signed in through your mobile device for it to work with Android Auto.

8. To use Android Auto, you'll need an Android phone running Android 6.0 or higher, an active data plan, and the Android Auto app.

9. You can launch Android Auto by connecting your compatible device or by pressing the Android Auto icon on the touchscreen.
results.generated_response:
**How to set up Android Auto in a U‑Connect vehicle**

Below is a complete, step‑by‑step guide that incorporates every requirement, tip, and detail from the U‑Connect documentation.

---

### 1. Verify the prerequisites  

| Requirement | What to check / do |
|-------------|--------------------|
| **Smartphone OS** | Android 6.0 (Marshmallow) or higher. |
| **Data plan** | An active cellular data plan (Android Auto uses LTE/3G for maps, music, etc.). |
| **Android Auto app** | Installed on the phone (download from Google Play). |
| **Compatible phone** | Verify compatibility at **g.co/androidauto/requirements** (most recent Android phones are supported). |
| **Vehicle state** | The vehicle must be in **PARK** the first time you use Android Auto. |
| **Cable** | Use the **factory‑provided USB cable** that came with your phone; many aftermarket cables do not work reliably. |
| **Cellular coverage** | Be in an area with LTE/3G coverage; Android Auto will show signal strength in the upper‑right corner of the radio screen. |
| **Music/other apps** | Install and sign‑in to any music or navigation apps you want to use (Spotify, YouTube Music, iHeartRadio, Google Maps, etc.) **before** connecting. |

---

### 2. Connect the phone  

1. **Plug the phone into a media USB port** (not the charging‑only port) using the proper USB cable.  
2. The vehicle’s U‑Connect system will detect the phone.  
3. **First‑time connection** – if the Android Auto app is not yet on the phone, it will start downloading automatically once the phone is plugged in.  

> **Tip:** The Phone icon on the drag‑&‑drop menu bar will change to the Android Auto icon as soon as the phone is recognized.

---

### 3. Launch Android Auto  

- **Automatic launch:** Android Auto is set to start immediately when a compatible device is connected.  
- **Manual launch:** If it does not start automatically, tap the **Android Auto icon** that now appears on the touchscreen’s main menu bar.  

---

### 4. Accept permissions & complete setup (first use only)  

- Follow any on‑screen prompts on the phone and on the vehicle display (e.g., allow access to contacts, messages, location, etc.).  
- Accept the “Vehicle Branded App” permissions if you wish to use remote features (horn, lights, etc.).  

---

### 5. Use voice recognition (VR)  

- **Steering‑wheel button:** Press and hold the **VR button** on the steering wheel.  
- **Touchscreen microphone:** Or press and hold the **Microphone icon** inside Android Auto.  

This activates Android Auto’s natural‑language voice assistant, letting you:  

- Send/reply to texts (read aloud, dictate).  
- Place/receive hands‑free calls.  
- Issue navigation commands, control music, etc.  

---

### 6. Control Android Auto  

- **Touchscreen:** Tap icons, cards, or lists.  
- **Steering‑wheel knobs/buttons:** Navigate menus, adjust volume, change tracks.  
- **Voice only:** Use VR for a hands‑free experience.  

---

### 7. Optional: Wireless Android Auto (if your vehicle supports it)  

1. Ensure your phone supports **wireless Android Auto** (most recent flagships do).  
2. Pair the phone to the vehicle via **Bluetooth** and **Wi‑Fi Direct** (the vehicle will prompt you).  
3. Follow the same on‑screen steps as the wired setup.  

> **Note:** Wireless use still requires a data plan and cellular coverage.

---

### 8. Troubleshooting quick‑checks  

- **Cable issues:** Switch to the original USB cable; many aftermarket cables fail.  
- **Phone not recognized:** Make sure the vehicle is in **PARK**, the USB port is a media port, and the phone’s USB mode is set to “File Transfer/Charging.”  
- **App not launching:** Tap the Android Auto icon manually; verify the Android Auto app is installed and up‑to‑date.  
- **No data:** Confirm you have LTE/3G coverage; Android Auto will display signal strength in the upper‑right corner.  

---

### 9. Summary checklist  

- [ ] Android 6.0+ phone with active data plan  
- [ ] Android Auto app installed (Google Play)  
- [ ] Compatible music/navigation apps installed & signed‑in  
- [ ] Factory‑provided USB cable (or wireless‑compatible phone)  
- [ ] Vehicle in **PARK** for first connection  
- [ ] Good cellular coverage (LTE/3G)  
- [ ] Connect phone to media USB port → Android Auto icon appears → launch → use voice or touchscreen controls  

Once these steps are completed, Android Auto will be fully functional on your U‑Connect touchscreen, allowing you to stream music, navigate, send messages, and control many other apps safely while driving.

results.question: Can I deactivate the DRLs?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the provided context, it seems that the ability to deactivate the Daytime Running Lights (DRLs) depends on the specific vehicle and the market it is sold in.

For vehicles sold in Canada, the context indicates that the headlight switch does not have an "OFF" detent. Instead, the headlights will be deactivated when the headlight switch is placed in the parking lights position. However, the DRLs will still be activated along with the front and rear marker lights in this scenario.

The context also mentions that the DRLs may be deactivated when the parking brake is engaged, and that for vehicles sold in Canada, the DRLs will automatically deactivate when the front fog lights are turned on.

Additionally, the context states that on some vehicles, the Daytime Running Lights may deactivate or reduce intensity on one side of the vehicle when a turn signal is activated on that side, or on both sides of the vehicle when the hazard warning lights are activated.

However, the context does not explicitly state that the DRLs can be manually deactivated by the driver. The information provided suggests that the ability to deactivate the DRLs may be limited or controlled by the vehicle's design and features, rather than being a user-configurable option.

Therefore, based on the given context, it is not clear if the DRLs can be deactivated by the driver. The ability to deactivate them may depend on the specific vehicle model and market regulations.
results.generated_response:
**Yes – the DRLs can be turned off, but only in the ways the vehicle’s design allows.**  

From the provided information the DRLs will deactivate (or dim) under the following conditions:

| Situation | Effect on DRLs |
|-----------|----------------|
| **Parking brake is engaged** (for vehicles sold in Canada) | DRLs are turned off. |
| **Front fog lights are turned on** (Canada‑spec models) | DRLs automatically deactivate. |
| **Turn signal is activated on one side** | DRL on that side may dim or turn off. |
| **Hazard warning lights are activated** | DRLs on both sides may dim or turn off. |
| **Low‑beam headlights are on** | DRLs are no longer active (they operate only when low beams are off). |

There is **no separate “DRL‑off” switch** mentioned in the context; the only ways to deactivate them are the above functional conditions (parking brake, fog lights, turn signals/hazards, or low‑beam use). If you need the DRLs off more permanently, you would have to use a dealer‑authorized method (e.g., re‑programming or fuse removal), but that is not described in the provided material.

results.question: What can the SOS Call button do?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Based on the context provided, the SOS Call button on the vehicle's overhead console has the following functionalities:

1. Initiating an SOS call to an SOS operator:
   - Pushing the SOS Call button will initiate a call to an SOS operator.
   - The SOS Call system will transmit important vehicle information to the SOS operator, including the vehicle brand, last known GPS coordinates, and an indication that the occupant placed an SOS call.

2. Cancellation of the SOS call:
   - There is a 10-second delay before the SOS Call system initiates the call to the SOS operator.
   - During this 10-second delay, the SOS Call can be canceled by pushing the SOS Call button again or by pressing the cancellation button on the device screen.
   - Terminating the SOS Call will turn off the green LED light on the overhead console.

3. Voice connection with the SOS operator:
   - Once the SOS Call connection is established, the occupants can speak with the SOS operator through the vehicle's audio system to determine if additional help is needed.

4. Emergency response assistance:
   - The SOS operator may attempt to contact appropriate emergency responders and provide them with the vehicle's important information and GPS coordinates.

In summary, the SOS Call button allows the vehicle occupants to initiate an emergency call, communicate with the SOS operator, and potentially receive emergency assistance if needed.
results.generated_response:
The SOS Call button lets you instantly request emergency assistance. When you press it, the vehicle:

* Starts a call to a SiriusXM Guardian SOS operator (you have a 10‑second window to cancel the call).  
* Sends key vehicle data to the operator, such as the vehicle’s make/model and the last‑known GPS coordinates.  
* Opens a two‑way voice link through the vehicle’s audio system so you can speak with the operator and be heard inside the vehicle.  
* Lights a green LED on the console to indicate that a connection has been made.  

In short, the SOS Call button initiates an emergency call, transmits location and vehicle info, and provides a voice channel for help.

results.question: How to make my steering wheel heated?
results.ground_truth_answer: To make your steering wheel heated, you need to locate the heated steering wheel button on the center of the instrument panel below the radio screen, or within the Climate or Controls screen of the touchscreen. Press the heated steering wheel button once to turn the heating element on. Press the button again to turn the heating element off. Remember, the engine must be running for the heated steering wheel to operate. Additionally, be cautious as the heating element can cause burns, especially if used for long periods, so individuals with certain physical conditions should be extra careful when using it. Do not place anything on the steering wheel that insulates against heat to avoid overheating.
results.generated_response:
To turn the heated‑steering‑wheel feature on:

1. **Start the engine** – the heater will not work unless the engine is running (or the vehicle is in Remote‑Start mode with the engine running).  
2. **Locate the button** – it’s on the center of the instrument panel just below the radio screen, and it also appears on the **Climate** or **Controls** screen of the touchscreen.  
3. **Press the button once** – this activates the heating element. The wheel will stay heated until you turn it off.  
4. **To turn it off**, press the same button a second time.

**Additional notes**

- The heater has only one temperature setting and will not turn on if the wheel is already warm.  
- Voice commands cannot control the heated steering wheel; they only adjust interior temperature.  
- When using Remote Start, the heated steering wheel (and driver’s heated seat, if programmed) will automatically turn on if you’ve set it in the Comfort menu.  

**Safety reminder**  
If you have reduced skin sensation (e.g., due to age, diabetes, medication, etc.), use the heater with caution to avoid burns. Do not cover the wheel with blankets or steering‑wheel covers, as they can cause the heater to overheat.

results.question: Can I change the desired speed when the Cruise Control is on?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yes, you can change the desired speed when the Cruise Control is on. The context provided indicates that you can do this by:

1. Pushing the SET (+) or SET (-) button when the vehicle has reached the desired speed. This will set the new desired speed.

2. If the vehicle speed is below 20 mph (32 km/h) when you set the cruise control, the set speed will default to 20 mph (32 km/h).

3. If the vehicle speed is above 20 mph (32 km/h) when you set the cruise control, the set speed will be the current vehicle speed.

So in summary, the instructions clearly state that you can adjust the desired speed by using the SET (+) and SET (-) buttons while the Cruise Control is active.
results.generated_response: Yes. While Cruise Control is on, you can adjust the set speed by pressing the **SET (+)** or **SET (‑)** button. Release the button after each press and the instrument cluster will show the new speed. (The vehicle should be traveling at a steady speed on level ground when you make the adjustment.)

results.question: What is special about power windows?
results.ground_truth_answer: Power windows have an Auto-Down feature where the window will go down automatically if the window switch is pushed down past the detent and released.
results.generated_response:
Power windows are operated by push‑button switches rather than a manual crank, and the driver‑ and front‑passenger‑side switches have an **Auto‑Down** function – if you push the switch down past the detent and release it, the window will continue to lower automatically.  

Other notable points are:

* The switches are on the instrument panel (below the climate controls) and also on the rear‑center console for the rear windows.  
* The system stays powered for up to **10 minutes after the ignition is turned off** (opening a front door cancels this).  
* There is **no anti‑pinch protection** when the window is almost closed, so objects must be cleared before closing.  
* Safety warnings stress keeping children away from the switches and never leaving a key fob where they can reach it.  

These features—button operation, auto‑down capability, post‑ignition power‑on time, and the associated safety precautions—make power windows special.

Push the switch downward to open the window and pull upward to close the window.  The driver door power window switch and the front passenger door power window switch have an Auto-Down feature.  Push the window switch down, past the detent, and release and the window will go down automatically.  Power Window Switches Never leave children unattended in a vehicle, and do not let children play with power windows.  Do not leave the key fob in or near the vehicle, or in a location accessible to children.  Occupants, particularly unattended children, can become entrapped by the windows while operating the power window switches.  Such entrapment may result in serious injury or death.  The power window switches will remain active for up to 10 minutes after the ignition is placed in the OFF position.  Opening either front door will cancel this feature.  There are window switches located on the rear of the center console for the rear passenger windows.

 Auto-Down Feature The driver door power window switch and the front passenger door power window switch have an Auto-Down feature.  Push the window switch down, past the detent, and release and the window will go down automatically.  To open the window part way, push the window switch down briefly, without going past the detent, and release it when you want the window to stop.  To stop the window from going all the way down during the Auto-Down operation, pull up on the switch briefly.  WARNING: There is no anti-pinch protection when the window is almost closed.  Be sure to clear all objects from the window before closing.

 Power Door Locks — If Equipped The power door lock switch is located on each front door panel.  Push the switch forward to unlock the doors, and rearward to lock the doors.  WARNING: For personal security reasons and safety in a collision, lock the vehicle doors when you drive, as well as when you park and exit the vehicle.  When exiting the vehicle, always place the ignition in the OFF position and remove the key from the vehicle.  Unsupervised use of vehicle equipment may cause severe personal injuries and death.  Never leave children alone in a vehicle, or with access to an unlocked vehicle.  Allowing children to be in a vehicle unattended is dangerous for a number of reasons.  A child or others could be seriously or fatally injured.  Children should be warned not to touch the parking brake, brake pedal or the gear selector.  Do not leave the key fob in or near the vehicle or in a location accessible to children.  A child could operate power windows, other controls, or move the vehicle.
